natural problem: What is the remainder when $x^2+7x-5$ divides $2x^4+11x^3-42x^2-60x+47$?
natural solution: \end{array} \]Since the degree of $2x-8$ is lower than that of $x^2+7x-5$, we cannot divide any further.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 2 + 7 * x - 5"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x powr 4 + 11 * x powr 3 - 42 * x powr 2 - 60 * x + 47"
and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. Q x = P x * R x + (2 * x - 8)"
shows  "R x = 2 * x - 8"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $x^2+7x-5$ divides $2x^4+11x^3-42x^2-60x+47$? The final Answer is 2x-8
 ### Proof
 \[ \begin{array}{c|cc ccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{2x^2} & -3x & -11 \\ \cline{2-6} x^2+7x-5 & 2x^4 & +11x^3 & -42x^2 & -60x & +47  \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{-2x^4} & -14x^3 & +10x^2 \\ \cline{2-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & -3x^3 & -32x^2 & -60x \\
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & +3x^3 & +21x^2 & -15x \\ \cline{3-5} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 & -11x^2 & -75x & +47 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{} &  & +11x^2 & +77x & -55 \\ \cline{4-6} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} &  & 0 & 2x & -8 \\
 \end{array} \]Since the degree of $2x-8$ is lower than that of $x^2+7x-5$, we cannot divide any further.
 So our remainder is $\boxed{2x-8}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 2 + 7 * x - 5"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x powr 4 + 11 * x powr 3 - 42 * x powr 2 - 60 * x + 47"
and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. Q x = P x * R x + (2 * x - 8)"
shows  "R x = 2 * x - 8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given that $P(x) = x^2 + 7x - 5$ and $Q(x) = 2x^4 + 11x^3 - 42x^2 - 60x + 47$, find a function $R(x)$ such that $Q(x) = P(x) * R(x) + (2x - 8)$, where $P(x)$ is a divisor of $Q(x)$. The final answer is $R(x) = 2x - 8$.

shows  "R x = 2 * x - 8"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $x^2+7x-5$ divides $2x^4+11x^3-42x^2-60x+47$? The final Answer is 2x-8

 \[ \begin{array}{c|cc ccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{2x^2} & -3x & -11 \\ \cline{2-6} x^2+7x-5 & 2x^4 & +11x^3 & -42x^2 & -60x & +47  \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{-2x^4} & -14x^3 & +10x^2 \\ \cline{2-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & -3x^3 & -32x^2 & -60x \\

 \end{array} \]Since the degree of $2x-8$ is lower than that of $x^2+7x-5$, we cannot divide any further.
 So our remainder is $\boxed{2x-8}$.
 *)
